thanks. Have you noticed that "apply permissions to enclosed files" do.. uh... nothing?
i have not

gets a little old. I'm a terminal junkie, but really? It's a bit of a headache when grandma moves files to/from an external drive and permissions are out of wack and I need to remote in to issue a chmod -R command.
its annoying if it doesnt do what it says on the box. Did you check the sub files are all owned by the same user?

that's where the issue is. The files came through as root:root on the external, but if you take ownership of the root folder, you SHOULD be able to take owner ship of the sub files/folders inside. Dolphin does this just fine.

it basically will transfer perms, but not ownership/group, which is kind of a royal PITA that there's no other way to do it than terminal. Again, I have no issue with it, but grandma does. Grandma would rather buy a windows license at the moment...
well not recursively disowning root is a good thing i suppose, but cant you access the external disk as a user and avoid having the files owned by root in the first plaec?

typically yeah - but when I take a folder that is owned by root with files in it, it comes down as owned by ME since I'm writing that folder to my home directory. But the files inside remain as root... hence the issue.
also how is she moving files as a user which are subsequently owned by root?
yeah.
you cant copy files and have copies owned by root, unless you are root
either way if you're in nautilus as root, you should be able to handle this task. Dolphin can do it without an issue.
that's another thing I may have forgotten to mention, about using gksudo nautilus.
gksudo nautilus.
running nautiuls as root may well cause half the problems you are having
point is, nautilus as root DOES NOT work in the same demeanor that dolphin does.

running it as root is sheer madness though
